Sometimes, it difficult to compete with others like this without falling exhausted. But knowing I can help a patient in some way, brings me back for another day.

cons: -Below-market compensation and benefits -Too big! Disseminating information throughout the organization is inefficient and time-consuming. Affecting change takes a long time. -Physicians with little knowledge and training about operations/administration of the hospital have a lot of say in it. -Lots of specialities being a large hospital, but also can be very siloed as a result.

job_title: Business Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: -Amazing workflow. I've been working since I was 16 and I've never had a better workflow than this position, -Perkspot has tons of benefits, but you have to look yourself because no one will tell you about it. -Interaction with most of the families is meaningful and fulfilling.
cons: -Not competitive pay -Management has favorites, and if you aren't one of them, you'll have fewer and less significant raises, less overtime approved when you try to pick up, get signed on for mandatory OT without being asked, and don't get their support in mediating workplace conflicts -HR refuses to step in and instead reports to management who only grow more hostile the more complaints you make -Outside the unit alone and without a barrier between visitors and the reception desk. The NNICU is a high stress unit, so sometimes families can lash out. It doesn't feel safe and management refuses to advocate for modifications to the desk.

review_title: Pros and Cons of working for a large hospital system--> you're a number
job_title: Registered Nurse (BSN
pros:
- More resources than at a smaller hospital (but then they can also be really stingy with resources and staffing so it's not as abundant as one might expect)
- 403B matching
- PTO (many professions don't have this)
- High risk hospital--> more critical patients which makes it fast paced and intense (this is also a con for some people)
cons:
- It is first and foremost a business 
- They pretend to care about their employees for publicity but it's really just for show- we are just numbers for staffing and easily expendable--> they will use you until you burn out; it's a systematic problem that management is a part of and perpetuates but I'm sure could also get caught in the bad end of the deal if they don't go with the "party line"
- No floor is managed consistently- the policies on requesting days off and scheduling are all different
- Poor staffing ratios on a systematic level plus it being a high risk hospital/more acute and critically ill patients makes the level of stress on nurses much higher than at other hospitals, especially given that there is poor support

job_title: Registered Nurse- Neuro ICU in New Haven, CT
pros: Lots of resources Lots of education Lots of research happening Good benefits Good pay
cons: All nurses are started as rotating days/nights 50/50. It took four years to get a straight day shift position in the ICU. Some extra documentation required because of Magnet status.

job_title: Staff Nurse II in New Haven, CT
pros:
- Great teamwork - plenty of resources and help available when needed. Cannot emphasize enough how supported I felt when working there!
-The entire interdisciplinary team is very collaborative and nursing opinions are respected/welcomed.
- They prioritize safe ratios and staff accordingly.
- Newer, well-designed unit with private rooms. I've since been in other units with private rooms and didn't realize just how well-thought out the unit at Yale was until I had left!
cons:
- Growth for staff nurses can be a slower process vs other facilities I've worked in. I came in with previous NICU experience so it was not an issue for me, but they typically wait 1-2+ years to orient new NNICU RN's to sicker patients, admissions, etc. It can create a divide between "ICU" vs "non-ICU" nurses.
- Rotating schedules between days/nights, sometimes within the same week was PAINFUL. And if you want straight day shift it can take 5+ years to get out of doing at least 1-2 nights per monthly grid.

job_title: Patient Care Assistant (PCA) in New Haven, CT
pros: Super flexible schedule, nice management team, updated equpment

job_title: Registered Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros: Great place to start nursing career

job_title: Pharmacist in New Haven, CT
pros:
Benefits including PTO are okay.. Yale NH Hospital Pharmacy Dept is excellent in Self-Promoting itself.

Management is also good at getting themselves promoted within their "circle of management friends".
cons:
Chaotic workplace with technicians running over the pharmacists and management not at all concerned by the rapid turnover of staff. They coined a term - Rxpect as in Pharmacy Respect yet are hypocritical and do not care about employee and patient safety. 

It was one of the worst managed pharmacies I have ever worked for. Demands are unrealistic beyond reason.

Given a choice of hiring the best candidate for a position or hiring someone they know or a family member of an employee, they invariably hire someone they know or the family member.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros: Diverse community, competitive salary, professional atmosphere, Potential for Growth
cons: management can play favoritism with certain employees. Strick policies and regulations, need to abide by the rule book or disciplinary action will take place. This may or not be a bad thing for some, but if you are looking for a position that you can just come in and do your work and go home, you have to remember you are working for a magnet hospital that likes to maintain their status. That said, they encourage you (and some have forced you) to become more involved by joining a group or committee. They also encourage you to climb the clinical ladder. This can be minimally rewarding with a slight bump in pay and is also a perk on your resume, but requires some time to dedicate to your project, and may require presenting to a committee or board before it is approved. The object is to help improve the unit and ease the work for the staff with whatever it is you choose to change.

review_title: Felt like a McDonalds of Healthcare: big brand name, poor quality. A patient mill.
job_title: Registered Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits are competitive.  The pay is competitive for the market in CT.  The facility itself is well-kept.
cons:
Cumbersome process for lateral transfers; recruiters in HR were all but useless, I thought.  I worked in nursing and I wanted to switch from one specialty to another. I was advised that the best way to transition to my specialty of choice was to transition to another semi-related specialty first, even though my heart wasn't set on that and it would have just wasted money on training me.   I ended up looking outside of the organization.

Also, the organization nickels and dimes employees through payroll deduction and parking fees.  They also routinely ask for you, the employee, to donate to the hospital.  Hartford and Middlesex do not do this.

Lastly, too many chiefs, not enough indians.  The nursing units constantly run with an excess of managers and assistant managers and an acute shortage of floor staff.  Not a great place to work.

job_title: Medical Technologist in New Haven, CT
pros: Good benefits, good pension, dedicated staff who cares about the patient, strong team effort. Hispital has a good reputation in the community.
cons:
If you punch in more than 3 mins late, you get points. If you are sick and miss a shift, you gain points, if you forget to punch out, you get points. Points lead to disciplinary action. When Yale bought St. Raph's they didn't lay off. They are using this system to cull the ranks. The point system causes a great deal of stress. 

Additionally the lab was understaffed and management was aware. Their business model was to push Med techs harder and faster instead of having the appropriate number of Med techs to fill the shift. Pushing like this leads to errors but errors lead to disciplinary action. There was so much pressure and stress here for these two reasons.

job_title: Case Manager/Utilization Review in New Haven, CT
pros: I strongly recommend YNHH if you are looking for a hospital employer.  I am a seasoned employee having worked in 4 states over nearly 40 years . YNHH cares about their employees as well as their patients equally.  They provide excellent care while being good stewards of the monies they receive from insurances. There is no impropriety here, I know, I review charts on a daily basis. I can’t say this for every hospital that I have been employed.  I highly respect this hospital. They provide excellent benefits.  They expect their employees to work hard to provide the best care to their patients.  I admire their ethics.
cons: There are always growing pains and heavy top management in every large corporation. I believe YNNH attempts to continue to work on this daily to make it a great place to work.

job_title: Medical Interpreter in New Haven, CT
pros: As an interpreter, I love to facilitate the communication between patients and providers. The need for interpreting services exists in every department within the hospital. One has the chance to meet diverse people and help to explain medical conditions and available treatments, as well as learning new terminology very often. The schedule is not strenuous and the payment is good.
cons: The department is very disorganized and does not promote the jobs around the hospital, letting these jobs be taken by phone-interpreters or freelance interpreters with more costly and less effective outcomes.

review_title: Lab Medicine at Yale New Haven Hospital
job_title: Laboratory Associate in West Haven, CT
pros: This is a great place to work if you like to learn, since this is a teaching hospital they give their employees the opportunity to learn in the job setting they are in.  They also give you the opportunity to make the extra money you need to help with added expenses in your life.  They have all kind of incentive that will keep you in a happy place.
cons: The only cons is that this hospital care about their patients so they expect your to have the same attitude when working around them.

job_title: Exercise Specialist in New Haven, CT
pros: YNHH has a great reputation and is a great place to start. Mostly great co-workers who became great friends. You must adhere to high standards and produce great quality work (your manager expects no less from you), and this will make you a shining star wherever you go afterward. Supervisors will typically give you room to be involved and have a voice (even if no one hears it).
cons: Minimal hours and pay. Parking is typically off-site and quite expensive. Organizational politics may stifle your growth and keep you in a box. For example, your responsibilities may be extremely limited if you hold a bachelor's degree. A master's degree may be required to gain clearance to do simple, menial tasks.

job_title: in Oakdale, CT
pros: No PRo's-Upper management DOES NOT PRACTICE WHAT THEY PREACH!!!!  They are non-exitent and you are left alone to make decisions-the only time you hear from them is if it wasn't the right decision despite the fact that you tried to ask for assistance.  They are way too large and overwork their nurses and are now starting to give them even more responsibility.  I would never have a family member be treated their, the last time was a disaster.  They are greedy, and I decided to leave because it was against my morals to stay their.
cons: See Pro's column-there are too many con's to write about,  They make the pay good to get you to come but your life is miserable working their-it is not worth any amount of money if you end up taking your job home with you.

job_title: Business Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits are great except that you have to pay for parking
cons: Management is very unorganized. They don't care about there employees. I was currently employed and got injured working with patients and was let go because I got injured working. I'm still not able to work and they continue to not pay for anything associated with worker's comp. Management makes every excuse to not help employees to improve within the corporation. There is no structured and it was one of the worst places I have ever worked.

job_title: ED Tech in New Haven, CT
pros: I work per diem and have for 2 of my 3 years while going to school; the managers have been wonderful in making sure they can find me enough hours every month to keep my employment while being flexible with my school schedule. Management also fosters a teamwork and cohesive staff environment, and you never feel like you have to do anything alone or without help if you need it.
cons: The parking situation is horrendous- I suggest public transportation if you can to save your money. Also, the fact that we only get 30 min lunch can be kind of ridiculous; 45 min, even if not an hour would be amazing.

job_title: Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: My department is a loving, caring, wonderful group of people, who work hard and help each other out to do our part for the patients.
cons: Management does NOT have our backs. Mistakes are approached with "who did it....find that staff member, humiliate and punish them" approach. Many of the OR nurses bully us, look down, on us, and we are trying to help them, they are rude, mean, and insensitive, and disrespectful, think they are smarter and better than anyone who isn't a nurse. We all care for patients, not just nurses. We are also short staffed, and the Owens and Minor reps are not very helpful.

review_title: Great Place to work for if you have the right attitude
job_title: Registered Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros: The benefits are good, though taciturn with the changing health and insurance system. The people you work with can also be great, though every unit will have the people that only see their personal advancement and care about nothing else
cons: Management can sometime be careless when making schedules or aviding by the shifts you were hired foR. Understaffing is a very big problem, specially since it put the loves of patients at risk

review_title: It's a great place to work
job_title: Patient Care Technician in New Haven, CT
pros: Working for Yale New Haven Hospital  give a lot of experience in the medical setting, there is a lot that I have learn, and  still learning on a daily basis.
cons: Unfortunately at time suggestions will be made to help with the population or for a more controled atmosphere, but, unfortunately because it's not coming from a member of the management team it's never heard of again or even implemented.

review_title: Don't let the name fool you.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros:
Zero pros. Their motto might as well be "profits over patients."  Understaffed on the majority of the units. 
HR could care less and appears to be brain washed by upper management.
cons:
Zero support from management. 
Zero support from HR. 
Surrounded by lazy coworkers who are untouchable due to favoritism from manager. 
Only people of color seem to be given fair treatment, management is in fear of the race card being pulled.

If you want to be over worked, under paid, and unappreciated then this is the place for you!

review_title: Great place to work- depending on department
job_title: Nurse Practitioner in New Haven, CT
pros: Some of the best people I have ever met and worked alongside. They have your back and stick together to get the job done for the patient
cons: My compensation and schedule are good for the area, and my management is awesome. But I have to keep it buttoned up, because most of the other employees seem pretty unhappy with their schedule or managers or demands

review_title: watch your own back and hope you are a "chosen one"
job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker in New Haven, CT
pros: after several years you can work your way to decent salary and if you can do this job you can do anything
cons: management is horrible- plays favorites and a bunch of mean girls some who are like snakes and can't pass the buck enough or a self righteous control freak who will schedule your every second- they promote the same incompetent people and jobs are made up for the favorites so you can NEVER move  from your position- pay for parking, they cannot hold onto drs and the staff that have been there for years abuse FMLA going out for weeks for the minor things and guess who covers their work??? the staff are sicker than the patients

job_title: Material Handler in New Haven, CT
pros: Tuition reimbursement, PTO, benefits, 401k, PIP
cons: Zero confidence in management, no support from HR, unsafe work environment, no opportunity to advance, no diversity in management

job_title: Medical Assistant in New Haven, CT
pros: Good pay with annual increases.  Accrued pto each pay period.  Responsive managers.  Flexibility and diverse opportunity.  Excellent RNs and APRNs.  Growing health care system which offers a variety of settings.
cons: Health benefits too expensive, with high deductibles, copays. Mandatory union membership for medical assistants with payroll deductions every pay period. Parking cost high and off site, shuttle to campus.

review_title: I used to love this place....
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Very diverse, friendly atmosphere, decent benefits, location
cons:
Poor Mgmt, unorganized. Employees are not compensated fairly or equally.Policies are inconsistent, they make up rules as they go.  They adhere to certain standards and pay scales, however within those scales compensation varies widely for all the wrong reasons. The unfairness and inequities are astonishing. 

 Rarely are there opportunities for advancement unless you are in an entry level position.

job_title: Business Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: Good health insurance, especially for part time employment.
cons: Some PCAs did not do their job and management did not care.  I felt the patients were often ignored and had to wait too long for help with essentials like using the toilet.   Employees have to pay for parking.  Twelve and one-half hour shifts on weekends and holidays are too much to ask of employees who are making low wages.  Half-hour for lunch break is not paid.

job_title: Business Associate in New Haven, CT
pros: The people are beautiful, diverse, very friendly and you will always have someone willing to help. You feel like an extra large family. It's like going to a family reunion everyday.
cons: It's hard to get in because people don't leave. Most people have been there for over 20 years. Now that it's a magnet hospital they make it harder to get in because they want everyone to already have experience.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: Health insurance, retirement plan, tuition reimbursement, competitive pay
cons: Can't always use PTO, not all management listens to employee suggestions,  communication is poor from mid-level management, inflexible work schedules (depending on department)

review_title: Finance Worse place I’ve ever worked
job_title: Analyst in New Haven, CT
pros: Competitive pay and benefits . Can cash in PTO.
cons:
Workload is not distributed equally. No training and expected to adapt to the culture immediately. All processes are manual  and communication is non-existent- unless you are part of the click. Absolutely not a team environment. People purposely pretend not to know things so they don’t have to help train you. 
Management openly talks about pushing people out that they don’t like. HR should have a better handle on leaderships greed and abusive behavior.. What comes around goes around. You are losing good-hard working people...

job_title: Associate Director in New Haven, CT
pros: Good pay and benefits.
cons: Meanest boss I've ever had and HR did nothing despite huge turnover and many complaints.  Working environment was awful both physically (not clean, temperature issues, etc, ) and mental (micromanagement, abusive/walking on eggshells atmosphere).   The absolute worst place I've ever worked in my career.

job_title: Staff Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros:
Close to highways.  Nice cafe.
Interesting cases
cons:
Management does not respond to sexual harrassment and bullying .  They have policies against this behavior but do not address the behavior. Shift favoritism blatant.
Allow harrassment and retaliation to continue.   Do not honor verbal contracts made when you are being hired.
Management verbally abusive and not supportive.  Would not recommend.
This hospital Lies to staff and public.  Poor communication between staff and upper management.

review_title: Employee satisfaction, compensation seems to be pushed to the bottom of her 'todo' list
job_title: in New Haven, CT
pros: Many opportunities for growth, good benefits, ok compensation, large company, job security
cons: lack of respect for insubordinate employee positions

job_title: APRN in New Haven, CT
pros: A lot of fantastic staff and patients
cons: I feel like the hospital grew and management didn't grow with it. People are overworked. The best workers get burned out and leave without any response from management. Systems are set up that don't make any sense or are set up around specific people and when those people leave the system falls apart.

review_title: Big organization where people with less degrees or lower professional status can be stepped on.
job_title: Social Work in New Haven, CT
pros: Excellent opportunity to learn and practice.
cons: Too big and beaurucratic if you are looking to work for a team or become part of a family while working.

job_title: OP Specialty Coder III in Whiting, IN

cons: I was hired with an RHIT but after I started then I was told they wanted a “coding credential”.  I was unable to get it by the deadline and I resigned with the understanding that it was mutual to avoid termination in my file.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
pros: A lot of employee programs you can take advantage of. A stable hospital with qualified finance team that keeps it that way.
cons: It's a big place they try to communicate to employees but unless it's your section of the hospital you don't hear about it.

job_title: CNII in New Haven, CT
pros: Opportunities for growth, respectful environment encouraged

review_title: Decent place to work with a high workload.
job_title: Medical Technologist in New Haven, CT
pros: The pay and benefits are good. The laboratory has many different positions with high complexity testing areas available to expand your skill set.
cons: The workload can be pretty heavy. The laboratory services a large area of southern Connecticut. The work environment is pretty competitive which can be a plus or minus depending on your outlook.

job_title: Director in New Haven, CT
pros: CEO is of highest integrity possible, and a great leader.    Hospital is a leader in exemplary care of patients and families .  Staff members are treated with respect and have many opportunities for growth.
cons: Large institution, and sometimes difficult to get things done in a timely manner.

job_title: Clinical Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros: I'm a new grad, all the nurses on my floor have helped me learn the job, management is very supportive.  Great nurse to patient ratio in Smilow.
cons: Sometimes it moves very fast, but I think that's to be expected with inpatient acute care.

review_title: Ok for patients, terrible for staff.
job_title: Equipment Technician in New Haven, CT
pros: The pay is respectable in every department. There benefits are better than not having any. Overtime is available at times throughout the year.
cons: They treat you like you're replaceable. The only care for profit and it almost feels like a plantation. Your over worked, micro managed, and constantly looked down upon. If need be, get hired and use to find another job or school. Benefits aren't cheap and co-pays are high.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in New Haven, CT
pros: Some of the best reasons to work for Yale-New Haven Hospital is this organization truly values their employees and helps to improve the just culture.
cons: Some of the downsides to working for Yale-New Haven Hospital is trying to find the work life balance.

job_title: Clinical Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros:
Love working with kids 
Three day work weeks 
It's a teaching hospital so there are lots of wonderful learning opportunities 
Family centered rounds
cons:
Management cares more about appearances than patient care
No ratios
Parking is far and in a dangerous area to walk though 
Pay isn't good

review_title: It's a place to learn as much as you can for pharmacy technicians.
job_title: Inpatient Pharmacy Technician in New Haven, CT
pros: Was able to develop a lot of skills.
cons: There is not much room for growth.

job_title: Physical Therapist in New Haven, CT
pros: You rotate through multiple different service lines and are able to see many various types of pts as a level 1 trauma and comprehensive stroke center with multiple ICUs and step downs.
cons: Working rotating weekends and holidays. Time off and weekend schedules are planned far in advance.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros: Great hospital with a very dedicated staff. Overall management is good. Good relationships between nursing and physicians.
cons: Very large and busy acedemic medical center. If you are looking for a hospital where you will learn everyone's names - then Yale New Haven is not for you.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New Haven, CT
pros: Pip- performance incentive check yearly after 1000 hrs, subsidized benefits starting at 24 hrs. Employee recognition programs.  Looks great on a resume, financially stable.
cons: Parking costs, distance from parking to hospital

job_title: Medical Coding Specialist in Bridgeport, CT

cons: I can't think of any in my department

review_title: Some days, great; other day, not so great
job_title: Clinical Nurse I in New Haven, CT
pros: Supportive management on my unit.

review_title: Working here has its ups and downs

review_title: It is a great learning experience, a great place for growth in character and professional skills

review_title: Employees are nice, upper management are snakes

review_title: Responsive to resident concerns, Above average compensation

review_title: Dont believe that upper management cares about you.

review_title: Overall safe place to work with great learning potential.

cons: Conservative.  Large bureaucratic organization.  Slow to change.

job_title: CNII in Seymour, CT

cons: Inflexible scheduling, way too much concern about  irrelevant charting that continues to get longer and takes time away from patient care. Something that took 3 steps now takes 6 for charting purposes only. We are "punished" for using out rightfully earned PTO benefits buy getting points which lead to write ups and/or termination. Significantly lower pay than other hospitals.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Haven, CT
